Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Approximation Algorithms for Network Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental problems in network design have served as benchmarks for the development of new techniques and evaluating their effectiveness in combinatorial optimization. This proposal will investigate a class of connectivity problems including the traveling salesperson problem and its closely related variants such as the bridge connectivity augmentation problem, two-edge-connected subgraph problem and vertex connectivity network design problems, in order to design improved approximation algorithms by advancing current techniques and developing new methods. The proposal also develops new theoretical models for network design problems from practice that incorporate sub-additive demands in information aggregation, and that integrate inventory storage and vehicle routing costs in logistics planning.

Due to the ubiquity of their applications, and the fundamental nature of their theory, network design problems are important both in practice and theory. New methods developed can be incorporated into practical heuristic approaches for solving prototypically hard optimization problems of real-life scale that arise in a host of applications from communications to logistics networks. The theoretical analysis developed will improve the mathematically provable quality of fast heuristic solutions for this important class of computational optimization problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key societal advances of the last decade are enabled by thesurge of interconnection technologies have given rise to a varietyof problems requiring the design of networks with specificinter-connectivity requirements. Examples include the design,analysis and operation of supply chain networks, social networksand telecommunication networks. This proposal studied theoreticalproblems in network design that have served as model problems fordeveloping new techniques in the design of efficient algorithmsthat provide near-optimal solutions for them. Since these problemsare computationally hard to solve exactly, the project developedapproximation algorithms that focus on trading off running time foraccuracy of the derived solutions. This project advanced newalgorithm design ideas for two important problems: the travelingsalesperson problem that has been a long-standing benchmark problemin mathematical optimization, and an inventory routing problem thatintegrates inventory storage and vehicle routing costs in logisticsplanning. The work developed new algorithms for these problemsbased on uncovering underlying structure in these problems and theuse of mathematical programming relaxations.


Due to the ubiquity of their applications, and the fundamentalnature of their theory, network design problems are important bothin practice and theory. New methods developed can be incorporatedinto practical heuristic approaches for solving these hardoptimization problems at real-life scale. The theoretical analysisdeveloped establish the mathematically provable quality of new fastheuristic solution methods for these important classes of problems.


The project supported the doctoral training and development of fourgraduate students of which two are female, all of who will completetheir dissertations on topics related to the proposal in aninterdisciplinary area blending algorithms, combinatorics andoptimization.
